rawContent:
$BABA $90 billion in cash, against a $185 billion dollar market cap. No other major company in the world can claim such a large percentage of their market cap being made up by cash.  
 
In fact a real incredible statistic. Both $AAPL and $AMZN have LESS cash on hand than Alibaba, yet they have valuations that are 10x higher or more.  
 
It's not a question of if Alibaba will ever be higher by a meaningful amount, it's just a question of when. Eventually these numbers and these figures matter. $32 billion a year in Free Cash Flow also being poured on top of that cash balance.  
 
So I can't tell you when Alibaba will begin to receive a more appropriate valuation, but I can tell you that it will at some point.

$AAPL Chinese authorities are looking to support their markets, while the CSI 300 index hit a five-year low last week.

On Monday, the Chinese Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) warned that it would have "no tolerance" for short sellers, warning that those who dare to break the law "will lose their shirts and rot in prison".

The CSRC said on Tuesday that no new company would be allowed to use the securities refinancing mechanism, which allows brokers to borrow shares that they then lend to their customers to make short sales. Existing authorizations will be gradually removed.✍️✅☎️✅☎️✍️✍️✍️✍️✅☎️✍️✍️☎️✅
